headline: Oversight or overkill? Sessions grilled again by lawmakers
subHeadline: Attorney general again insists that he never lied under oath about Russia in new testimony to Congress.

Attorney General Jeff Sessions back on the hill today to answer more questions on the Trumps team contact with Russians after evidence emerged that two former campaign advisors told Sessions about their communications. utterances.speaker: SESSIONS
utterances.sentences: I would say the Department of Justice can never be used to retaliate politically against opponents and that would be wrong. A president cannot improperly influence an investigation. I have not been improperly influenced and would not be improperly influenced.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Republican congressman Jim Jordan followed up with this. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: REP. JIM JORDAN, R-OHIO
utterances.sentences: What's it going to take to actually get a special counsel?

utterances.speaker: SESSIONS
utterances.sentences: It would take a factual basis that meets a standard of the appointment of a special counsel.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Is that analysis going on right now?

utterances.speaker: SESSION
utterances.sentences: It's in the manual of the Department of Justice about what's required. We've only had to two. The first one was the Waco, Janet Reno, Senator Danforth who took over that investigation as special counsel, and Mr. Mueller. Each of those are pretty special factual situations.

utterances.speaker: JORDAN
utterances.sentences: Let me ask --

utterances.speaker: SESSIONS
utterances.sentences: ...we would use the proper standards, and that's what -- only think I can tell you. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So do you think the DOJ should be investigating the Clinton Foundation for corruption?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Because here's one quick key question, the Clinton Foundation got all this money, $140 million whatever, from Russia. Imagine their joy and surprise over this because I don't remember the Russians doing a lot of charity giving in the United States. I mean, do they give stuff to Wounded Warriors, or United Way, or --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hurricane relief.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't think so. Must have been a real shock to them. Could have been any coincidence involved. I think that's a really key question here that have to be -- also, it's interesting how you can love the Russian so much, five years ago, to sell them nuclear material and then think they're awful people now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is that how politics works though in Washington? Where you people make a donation, and then maybe expect something in return. Is that criminal?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, that's what the Clinton Foundation said in their defense. Remember the New York Times first puts out this story in the early 2015, in the fall there, and the Clinton Foundation went berserk. They're like there's nothing wrong with this. This is just what we're doing. We're not saying that we were going -- there is no quid pro quo here for the Clinton Foundation if she were to become president that she's going to return the favor by reducing sanctions or whatever. I don't think there's ever been anything like that. Now I guess that there are enough people that believe that Uranium One and this decision that was decided by nine different departments, that which was one that perhaps maybe there's something there. And what Jeff Sessions is saying is that he asked the prosecution team at the justice department to look at the merits of the case. If the merits of the case warrant a special prosecutor, then he won't stand in the way of that. He is saying the president didn't push him into it. The calls upon him have been coming not just from the president but from Capitol Hill. You saw Jim Jordan his question is what it's going to take to get a special counsel. And Sessions is being very careful. He talked about literally doing it by the book because his answer is it's in the manual of the Department of Justice. So he's trying to be right down and be very steady and be the attorney general that he promised the congress he would be. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Perhaps there is a paper trail, Kimberly, and, you know, a quid pro quo. There could be evidence of that is you have Huma saying, oh, we've got some donations. Let's take a look at this. Or you have some Russians -- oh, how much money do you need kind of thing. And that's what the investigation might find out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, right. And I think -- you know, I like his by the book approach. And again, that's why I said -- you know, yes, it wasn't like so scintillating today, but I thought it was persuasive because this to me is a man who comes out that he's going to abide by the law. That he's going to follow it and go by the book. He is discussing the specifics in terms of how an investigation should take place, and also not ruling out a special counsel and future investigation. I think that's what Americans want to hear. To me he's not presenting like somebody who is a partisan person in terms of -- like we've seen, very politicized the office of, you know, the U.S. attorney that -- it's problem. It's really is when you see people like this and you say, OK, this guy actually wants to do a good job, and he wants to not be influence one way or the other. He wants to call it like he sees it. And he's also saying what they've done in the past is not OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It would be quite amusing, Juan, if the Russian investigation wound up causing investigation of the Hillary Clinton foundation.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Look at the smile.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I was looking at that smile. You know you're up to no good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yeah. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So it is political retaliation?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what Jesse is saying. Oh, no. How about this, am I Nikita Khrushchev or Donald Trump? I'm so mad. I don't control the law enforcement around here. Why doesn't the justice department go after those evil Clintons? Oh, who said that? I think it was Donald Trump before the Asian.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: It's more like Muhammad Ali.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Did that sound like Muhammad Ali to you? I was trying. He's pressuring Jeff Sessions who already said he doesn't it. Then why did he recuse himself? You caused me so much trouble with this guy, Mueller. Why doesn't he consider leaving -- all of a sudden, Sessions is now saying to Stephen Boyd, the assistant attorney general, oh, why don't you see if there's anything there for the Clintons. It sounds to me like pure, unadulterated political retaliation. Imagine if Obama had gone after the Bushes on waterboarding. Imagine if Bush had gone after Gore on the Buddhist temple fund-raising. This is not American. This is not normal. This is wrong.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, I remember after the election, Donald Trump said no, we're not going to lock Hillary up. He's going to let her off. And I think he might have had a change of mind after this whole Russia investigation got to where it got.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I mean, let's just compare the two segments we've done so far. The A-block was a hearing about a meeting. This is selling nuclear material to Russians. I guess they couldn't work out a deal selling knives to ISIS.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The uranium wasn't going to Russia. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Where did it go?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . the deal -- it couldn't leave the United States.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It did go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, it did not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It went to Canada, and then it went to Europe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Canada is not part of the United States.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It can't export the uranium. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It can't, but they did. And that's actually a fact. WILLIAMS: Let's say I don't agree with you, but let's just assume that you're right. Let's assume you're right. It was 2 percent -- this is nothing, zero. And yet, because Republicans are so.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Look, it did not open up the threat of additional nuclear weapons if that's what you're suggesting. That is ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Why did we give them uranium to begin with?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Asked the nuclear regulatory commission, ask everybody who was involved if you are so scared. That's not the issue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm not scared.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And remember -- we want control. We want influence over Russia's nuclear capabilities. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: If we want to influence, why did we give them all the uranium? Up next, more Republicans distancing themselves from Roy Moore as more allegations pile up. We'll have the latest.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: One by one, Republicans are calling on Alabama's GOP senate nominee to step aside as sexual abuse and harassment allegations mount. Now, House Speaker Paul Ryan joining the chorus on Roy Moore after another accuser comes forward.

utterances.speaker: SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE PAUL RYAN, R-WIS.
utterances.sentences: He should step aside. Number one, these allegations are credible. Number two, if he cares about the values and the people he claims to care about, then he should step aside.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Senate majority leader Mitch McConnell also said yesterday he believes the women and that Moore should go. But will Moore go? What are the options for Republicans? So Dana, some options have been discussed. A little bit -- a couple of chess moves we've discussed a little bit earlier. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Firs of all, they're all basing this on that he should step aside. Even President Trump said through a spokesperson that if these things are true, then he believes that Roy Moore will do the right thing and step aside. But Roy Moore has said he has no -- there's no intention of stepping aside. But he is starting to get squeezed. He is no longer being supported by the funding from the NRSC. I think it was 43 senate Republicans now who have said, OK, enough, you need to step aside. And a lot of the additional reporting is not good for him. I don't know if that matters in actual Alabama, right? This is a state election. It's not a federal election, even though we're all paying attention to it. This is for the state to decide. But I do feel like he's getting pretty squeezed.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, Jesse, some discussing, we talked about it saying, OK, Sessions back over to Alabama.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't know if Sessions wants to do that. Maybe he had to be physically place back in the seat where he came from. Listen, RBS meters went off when we heard the thing. We were right about it from the very beginning. The guy looks like a holy-roller hypocrite. This isn't just a he said-she said when it involves minors and now it's risen to the level of alleged sexual assault. We're hearing reports about him even signing high school girls' yearbooks when he's in his 30s. He allegedly banned from malls because he was trying to pick up teenagers. It just gets more and more gory and disgusting. And I feel terrible for the victims, if it's true, which it looks like -- these are very credible allegations as the house speaker said. Now, I think if you're someone on the far right or the right, you have to pick your battles. Is Roy Moore the hill you're ready to die on? I don't think so. I think there's a lot of other places you want to fight. I think sometimes you've got to know when to hold them, know when to fold them, and this might be one of those times. So I think everybody just kind of use your common sense here. This guy who's been convicted in the court of public opinion, do you want this guy representing Alabama in the Senate and representing your party? At this point, and it looks like the floodgates are still pouring open, I can't find many people in Alabama or in the country as a Republican that would want this guy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: All right. Well, he's not showing us any indication that he's going to leave or pull the rip cord on this, so where do you go?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what? But I do understand why the voters, even if it's likely so that he is guilty. I do think it was a hit piece, but I think it was a factual hit piece. You can have both. It doesn't to be either/or. It's one of those cases where we become prisoners of two ideas. He's either innocent and it's a hit piece, or you know, he's guilty and -- it could be a hit piece, and he could be guilty. But the problem with the -- I don't blame the voters for thinking that this is an attack because it happened a month before the election. And that -- I mean, that doesn't strike anybody -- if it happened to a liberal, they would go, this is a real -- this isn't a coincidence that it happened. So I understand.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It wouldn't have happened to a liberal. That's why people don't like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But the thing is, you cannot blame The Washington Post for doing its research. You can blame the Republican Party for not doing their research. Like, for example, why did -- why did they endorse Luther Strange? Did they know about this stuff? If they knew about this stuff, and they kept it to themselves, then they only have themselves to blame. They went for Luther Strange even though Luther Strange had some problems in his background, as well. So why did they make that choice? Maybe they heard what is now being called an open secret, which I hate that word. But -- words. But that's on the Republican Party for letting this get that far, if this stuff was common knowledge.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right. Well, the president endorsed, you know, Strange. He did not go for Roy Moore. I mean, you bring up a good point. What did anybody know war here or was there rumor, conjecture about this? It's interesting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: that reveals another side to the story which is Steve Bannon had backed Roy Moore. Steve Bannon is still with Roy Moore. What did anybody know or here, or was there kind of any rumor, you know, conjecture about this? It's interesting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that that reveals another side to the story, Kimberly, which is that, you know, Steve Bannon had backed Roy Moore. Steve Bannon is still with Roy Moore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: For now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And Mitch McConnell is the one who said to the Republican Party that Greg's talking about, "We're not backing Roy Moore. We want Luther Strange." Why? Luther Strange, one, is a reliable vote for Republican causes, including President Trump, which is ultimately what persuaded Trump to back him. But the bigger issue for the Republican Party overall is, given their experience in recent cycles with candidates who say things like legitimate rape and all the rest, it becomes toxic for the party. It suddenly becomes associated with the Republican brand. And from McConnell's point of view as the Senate majority leader, that's not good for Republicans. And I think that's what we're seeing now. I don't know what they knew, Greg. I don't know what they didn't know, but I know there's a civil war within the party. McConnell is on one side. Bannon is on the other. And now somehow Roy Moore has been elevated as, like, which side are you on? And I'm sorry to see that happen, because I don't think that, given the testimony...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Are you really sorry to see that happen?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right. Because you know why? You know what? I mean, you need two parties in this country. You don't -- you don't want to see politics break down.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But at what point does the president put some pressure?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What -- there wasn't a split with Anthony Weiner. I think when that happened, did anybody stick by him?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No. Even his wife is gone now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But you know what happened today, by the way, in the House that's interesting, is Paul Ryan has said he's going to go after setting a standard for harassment, sexual harassment in the Congress. I've never seen anything like that, because typically, that's -- that's a boys' club.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And it's also opening up a lot of questions about Juanita Broderick and a lot of the women that had accused Bill Clinton...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: ... of sexual improprieties. They weren't believed then, and a lot of people are saying now maybe there's more to that story.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: All right. Ahead, climate protesters are now breaking into song to sound the warming alarm bell. Hold your ears. There's some very bad karaoke, next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When the administration gave its pitch for coal and nuclear energy at the U.N. conference on climate change -- that's fun -- it was disrupted by evil demonstrators:

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The chart... PROTESTERS (singing): You claim to be an American, but we see right through your greed. It's killing all across the world for that coal money. And we proudly stand up until you keep it in the ground. The people of the world unite, and we are here to stay.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, that's as catchy as lice -- not as enjoyable. And as surprising as the gas you get after taco -- after eating a taco supreme. Trying to speak common sense at the U.N. is like trying to speak Chinese to a table lamp. And anything positive you say is going to get booed. The U.N. prefers dictators and socialism. If you want the U.N. to cheer you, promote failure and death. Their hatred for industry, be it nuclear or coal, is embedded in their hatred, ultimately, for capitalism. Even as we rid the world of its truly worst threat, which is ISIS, they still hate us for trying. But what can you expect from these climate deniers? That's what these protesters are: climate deniers. They refuse to believe the climate has changed -- one to sober analysis and fact. Here's what they deny: That coal would save millions of lives in poor countries by replacing the toxic, impure fuels they use and that the Paris Accords was a terrible deal that would also cost lives. You want to spend 100 trillion to capture a fraction of a degree Celsius? Research shows that less than half that cash could rid the world of poverty, hunger, disease and pollution. Using that cash carelessly is homicidal, which could be why the U.N. is in love with it. By the way, Syria just joined the Paris Accords, and by the U.N.'s logic, that country is far more compassionate than us. So what if you gas your own people? At least that drives down the carbon footprint.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Wow, terrible.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It is terrible. I love, Kimberly, how those protesters, because they're ignorant. They're ignorant. They're accusing those people on the podium of murder when, if they deny coal to third-world nations, 2 to 3 million, according to the Copenhagen Consensus -- 2.8 billion people use mostly wood and dung -- dung -- to cook and keep warm. That kills 2.8 million people each year from indoor air pollution. If you replace that with coal, you would save 3 million people's lives. These people are the murderers.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK, so they're accessories.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: To crime. I'm just doing what they do.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right, so they're accessories to...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Genocide, essentially, is what you're saying.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, that's where you have to arm yourself with the facts and understand the issues very clearly on this. They are -- you know, I mean, look, at least they're not Antifa. They're sort of singing in tune.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'm trying to be positive. They're not wearing masks...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: ... or weird outfits or, like, stabbing horses or whatever. But nevertheless, they are trying to unite and be expressive about an issue that they care about. But perhaps they're not as fully informed as they could be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ignorant. Ignorant people

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: This is the problem. So I don't know. They disrupted this. I like the little bouncing dot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, Dana, Bjorn Lomborg, he runs the Copenhagen Consensus Center. They calculate that for 37.5 trillion you could eradicate poverty, hunger, disease around the world. Around the world. Fix climate change, pollution, all that stuff, by 20 -- I think it's by...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thirty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: ... 2030. Yes. So if you don't do that, and you follow the climate accords, 100 trillion over -- one to two trillion a year, you kill those people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It absolutely makes financial sense. This is a case that President Trump could make pretty persuasively. If he wanted to give a speech about climate change and energy, someone like him could do what you're saying. But when you're saying they're the accessory to the murders?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Actually, why doesn't -- people with common sense actually do that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because we're nice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We've been too nice for too long. And actually, technological innovation is one of the things that they were talking about there, was how you can take, because we're going to deal with coal for a long time, how can you have technological innovations developed here in the United States, address the issue of coal, make it cleaner so that people can have the energy that they need so that we can develop even better more renewable energies.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, why do you hate poor people from third-world nations?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, if you really cared about poor people from third-world nations, Mr. Lecturer over here...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... you would -- you would understand that, in fact, in the Paris climate deal, there were concessions made to third-world countries to allow them to continue using coal and natural gas. And it was the United States as a world leader that said, "We're going to set an example in terms of coming back. Because we want you to cut back as you grow, as you get a larger middle class in places like China and Brazil." So that's why we were in the deal, which is now going forward. Again, yesterday, we...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: With Syria.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Now last -- that means we're the only country not in the deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because we're cool.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's it. Actually, we're warm, because we have coal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Good point.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But I would say this to your point, that you have people over there like Al Gore. I know you don't like Al Gore. And you have our former mayor, Michael Bloomberg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Michael Bloomberg had a great quote about this, because I agree with Dana, by the way, that they -- the Trump people had a legitimate point to make about the efficient use of coal and natural gas and saying, "Hey, if it's going to be used, let's think about it." But then you have the reality that people perceive them as such enemies, such -- so angry at the idea of trying to limit greenhouse gases that you have Michael Bloomberg say, "Promoting coal at the climate summit is like promoting tobacco at a cancer summit." That gives you an idea of how we are perceived now. By -- that's by our own...

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't help our perceptions, Jesse. And neither can you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No. Imagine if -- that's true. Imagine if you're the parent and you just spent $200,000 on your daughter to go to college, probably Middlebury or somewhere like that. And you said, "What do you do this weekend, Candace?" And she said, "I protested a coal conference at the U.N." You've got to think to yourself, that was not money well spent. And these people probably went to very nice schools, want to put coal miners in West Virginia out of work. That's what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's true, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: They're Hillary supporters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And their dorms are heated by coal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, because if you don't have coal, you don't have jobs in West Virginia and places like that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I see. And we don't have any jobs coming from...

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Keep losing.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: We don't have any jobs coming from real (ph) energy, alternative?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The other thing that's pretty funny, too, is that -- maybe Solyndra. How many jobs were there?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, the jobs?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I can still count them on my fingers. And think about, of all the tyrants and dictators and human rights abusers at the United Nations, these people decided to protest America. Think about that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I know. We -- America and others have destroyed ISIS. We're saving people's lives, and these people are protesting. It's disgusting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What about Lee Greenwood's song?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I think they did a nice rendition.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I thought.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Best part of the whole protest.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. Joe Biden -- you remember him -- hopes President Trump never happens again. His latest tie-rade, next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Tirade.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Tirade. Trade.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's good. Former Vice President Joe Biden have been parsing his words on President Trump while the president was overseas in Asia, but last night, he let loose when Stephen Colbert asked him what kind of impact the Trump presidency will have on his successors.

utterances.speaker: FORMER VICE PRESIDENT JOE BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I think, it will -- God willing, it will go down as the single exception in American history.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And then he exploded.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: How many of you are now worried about the stability of the republic? How many are now worried about this new phony nationalism, and it's "us against them"? How many are worried about this populism that is designed to essentially undermine the essence of the Bill of Rights? I mean, I just think there's an attack on the system. And I think people are worried.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Kimberly, he's out promoting a book called "Promise Me, Dad." It's about his son, Beau, who died from cancer, on his death bed saying, "Dad, I want you to run." What do you think? Do you think he's running?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, he seems like he's ready to run. You know, that his head is in the right place. He feels like that he has, you know, the most to offer. We followed up on this the other day, where he was like OK, do you think you're the best person for the job? Is your head completely in it? His answer to both those questions are "Yes, correct." And I think he probably has a little bit of, like, you know, regret that he didn't get ahead and, you know, go and run, and that Donna didn't, you know -- "Put me in, coach." He's ready to play. That's how I see it. And obviously, this is a good platform. He's well-liked in the Democratic Party. So I don't know. I wouldn't be surprised. I would not rule him out. He'll be part of the fray, like, climbing over each other to the top. Like, Warren and Kamala Harris. Right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So Jesse, in fact, when he was on NBC, NBC looked like it was having a coronation party. It was just, like, unbelievable. They gave him so much time. It looks like a lot of people are just -- on the liberal side are getting behind Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're surprised NBC gave a very soft interview to Biden?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know if it was a soft interview.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, did Matt Lauer play footsie with him during the halftime show? Something like (ph) -- football. The new guys were sitting there eating wings. It was very, very warming. Now I think the Democrats should run Dukakis, Al Gore, John Kerry, Biden, the oldest, whitest guys in the field.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Jimmy Carter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And see what happens. Is he allowed to run again?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He could be VP.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He could be VP.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It will make Biden look young.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right. You know, the problem is the Democrats right now, it's all about what they're against and not what they're for. And if the economy starts and continues to soar under President Trump, and they run against a very, very high-performing economy, that is going to be a very tough sell for them to do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Dana, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that if Joe Biden were to decide to run, it might scare off some of those younger Democrats. They'll think "I can't raise the money." But they're going to probably have 17 candidates in their primary, just like the Republicans had in 2016.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Greg Gutfeld for president?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I could never pass the research on that. But here's what I don't understand. He's all over the place. When he was talking to Matt Lauer, he said the country was doing well under Trump. He said that, and then they asked him for examples, and he didn't give them any. But he said things were going fine. So I think, you know, woo, there might be something going on. If he forgets -- oh, wait. Everybody says that about Trump, and you can say that about Biden. The other thing...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Biden and Pelosi.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It is getting to be an older party. They're going to need to add another "A" to "AARP."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, and the Republican president, I think he's 71. "One More Thing" is next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: High energy, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: High energy. That's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- K.G.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And it's time now for...

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Kimberly's Food Court.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Or "Kimberly's Pickle Court," whatever you want to call it. Because today is National Pickle Day, believe it or not. Did you even know that pickles -- look at Jesse, digging in. Yes, National Pickle Day. And according to the calendar website, it's been celebrated for nearly 70 years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So it's not, like, a new thing. And each year the United States consumes 5.2 million pounds of pickles. They are fat free and low in calories.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Mouthwatering.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Do they taste good to you, Jess?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Delicious.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: ... because I like them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. So I had some great visitors, the Kids' Day reporters, who are actually going to be on my show, our special Thanksgiving show, "The Greg Gutfeld Show." John Helou (ph) -- which I probably ruined his name, Harrison Handley (ph), Alex Happ (ph), Fred Chrysler (ph). They're all from Our Lady of the Hamptons School in Southampton, believe it or not. And they're going to be on my show. They grilled me on my history as a pseudo-journalist. And they tore me to pieces. But you know what they did? They brought gifts. Now, this is kind of funny. Because you know the Snickers bars, they have words on them, so they picked out a Snickers bar to describe each one of us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So for me, I was "Sarcastic."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And then for Dana, it was "Princess."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: For Jesse, it was "Oddball."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, "Confused." Confused. And of course, Kimberly, "Cray Cray."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's so cute. Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to eat all of them.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: While we talk about that, check out this video. It's bananas. This is a -- Jelani (ph). Jelani is a male gorilla. And he loves to look at people's videos. And with this guy, he sat there and he swiped all of the Tinder photos and Bumble photos, whatever they were. Back and forth, back and forth, because he loves to look at videos. He's so cute. All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. We've heard of an emotional support dog. Now an emotional support squirrel. That's right. We have a guy, Ryan Boylan in Florida -- of Clearwater, Florida, actually. He's got a squirrel named Brutus. He got into a car accident.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And instead of a dog, he has the squirrel for emotional support. And he's getting evicted from where he lives, because the residents don't like it. And on "Watters' World" this weekend, we will have Ryan and the squirrel on the show. We're going to hear his side of the story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Juan, we only have 20 seconds.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, let me see what I can do. LeBron James had an excellent adventure with his team's trip to New York yesterday. They were told it would take 45 minutes by bus to get back to the hotel after the shootaround in the morning. So they took a six-minute ride on the subway. The only problem, as he was doing a video, some of the New York strap handlers said...

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Got to run.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: ... "Get that camera out of my face."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. "Special Report" is up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2017 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2017 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
